form.steps:
1. Stand tall with your feet hip-width apart. 
2. Take a big step forward with one leg. 
3. Lower your body by bending both knees to a comfortable depth. 
4. Push through the heel of your front foot to return to the starting position. 
5. Repeat on the other side.

form.Torso: Keep your torso upright and core engaged throughout the exercise.
form.Front Knee: Ensure your front knee tracks over your toes and doesn't collapse inward.
form.Back Knee: Lower your back knee towards the ground without allowing it to touch.
form.Weight Distribution: Distribute your weight evenly between both feet.

commonMistakes.Excessive Forward Lean: Leaning too far forward, putting stress on the front knee.
commonMistakes.Knee Collapse: Allowing the front knee to cave inward, which can strain the knee joint.
commonMistakes.Heel Lift: Lifting the front heel off the ground, shifting the weight forward and potentially causing imbalance.
commonMistakes.Limited Range of Motion: Not lowering the body down far enough, reducing muscle activation.

comments.Purpose: Shallow lunges are a good alternative to regular lunges for individuals with mobility limitations or those new to the exercise.
comments.Progression: As your strength and mobility improve, you can gradually increase the depth of the lunge.
comments.Variations: You can add variations like lateral lunges or reverse lunges to target different muscle groups.
comments.Weight Addition: Once you can comfortably perform bodyweight shallow lunges, you can increase the difficulty by holding dumbbells or a barbell.

alternativesAndVariations.Bodyweight Lunge: A deeper variation of the lunge that increases the range of motion and muscle activation.
alternativesAndVariations.Reverse Lunge: Performed by stepping backward instead of forward, emphasizing the glutes and hamstrings.
alternativesAndVariations.Lateral Lunge: Involves stepping sideways instead of forward, targeting the inner and outer thighs.
alternativesAndVariations.Bulgarian Split Squat: A more challenging variation performed with the back foot elevated, increasing the load on the front leg.

shallow-lunges-bodyweight.tempo: 2010 (2 seconds lowering, 0 seconds pause at the bottom, 1 second lifting, 0 seconds pause at the top)
